awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Programming Non-Linear Waves in Compliant Mechanical Metamaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Enabled by developments in the additive manufacturing of engineered systems with unprecedented levels of compositional and structural complexity, there have been major advances in architected materials that possess exciting mechanical properties dictated by their engineered structure. Within the realm of dynamics, the idea of using engineered structures to produce novel properties has been historically focused primarily on linear waves. This work seeks to understand the propagation of non-linear waves in mechanical metamaterials with application toward control of mechanical signals in larger-amplitude loading (for example, to provide protection during impact events) and toward reconfigurable soft structures (for example, locomotion of soft robots). This research will promote interdisciplinary research and teaching. Students of all levels will learn concepts and techniques from materials science and engineering, computational and analytic mechanical modeling, advanced manufacturing, and sensing. Moreover, the research team will integrate these efforts with undergraduate research programs, outreach efforts, and educational material development at both institutions to provide research opportunities to underrepresented groups of all ages (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate).

The objective of this work is to understand the fundamental connection between geometry and the propagation of non-linear waves in compliant mechanical metamaterials comprising rotating polygons. Rather than limiting the scope to periodic systems as in previous work, the geometry of the metamaterials will be locally tailored, and inhomogeneities will be harnessed to achieve target dynamic responses such as maximal energy absorption, soliton lensing, and locomotion. The multi-faceted research program will intertwine theoretical, numerical, and experimental activities to generate new insights into the non-linear dynamic behavior of mechanical metamaterials based on rotating units. To achieve this, the research is organized into three thrusts, focusing on (1) the effect of inhomogeneities on the propagation of non-linear waves, (2) reconfigurability of system dynamics via non-linear waves, and (3) optimization of geometry and defects via machine learning to achieve targeted dynamic properties (energy absorption, steering waves, locomotion, etc.).

This project is co-funded by the Dynamics, Control, and Systems Diagnostics (DCSD) and the Mechanics of Materials and Structures (MOMS) programs in the Civil, Mechanical, and Industrial Innovation Division.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
Advances in fabrication and optimization tools have enabled researchers to design and produce architected materials with unprecedented mechanical properties. However, most previous work, particularly in dynamics, has focused on the study of homogeneous, periodic media. However, the design of the next generation of robots, large deployable structures for space, and safer cars and airplanes requires understanding how large-amplitude, non-linear waves propagate through inhomogeneous structures. In this work, we studied the propagation of bulk and surface non-linear waves in inhomogeneous systems of rotating squares.

The formal objective of this work was to understand the fundamental connection between geometry and the propagation of non-linear waves in compliant mechanical metamaterials comprising rotating polygons. We developed numerical models to translate these fundamental discoveries toward the design of target dynamic responses, including amplitude-dependent programmable reconﬁgurability of kirigami-inspired structures and trajectory stabilization in robotics. We structured the research eﬀort into three thrusts, focusing on (1) the eﬀect of inhomogeneities on the propagation of non-linear waves, (2) reconﬁgurability of system dynamics via non-linear waves, and (3) optimization of geometry to achieve targeted dynamic properties.

Intellectual merit: Advances in digital manufacturing have enabled fabrication of systems with an unprecedented level of compositional and structural complexity, stimulating major advances in designer matter with unique mechanical properties dictated by their engineered structure. Phononic and acoustic metamaterials are well-established examples of these, in which the engineered structure of the medium is used to control the propagation of linear waves. Non-linear dynamic counterparts are still rare, even though they have shown tremendous potential for controlling mechanical signals in larger-amplitude loading, such as impact events, or where instabilities and buckling are present, as in the design of soft robots. In this work we made fundamental contributions to this nascent ﬁeld, developing a much-needed theoretical framework; this framework was numerically and experimentally validated, and applied toward the design of optimal architectures for target dynamic responses (maximal energy absorption, wave-guiding, locomotion, etc.). These advances are relevant to researchers in ﬁelds as diverse as soft robotics, medical device design, and impact mitigation.

Broader impacts: As part of this eﬀort, we promoted interdisciplinary research and teaching. Students of all levels learned concepts and techniques from materials science and engineering, computational and analytic mechanical modeling, advanced manufacturing, and sensing. The project facilitated student collaboration across a range of disciplines, and leveraged undergraduate research programs, outreach eﬀorts, and educational material development to provide opportunities to diverse groups of all ages (K-12, undergraduate, graduate).

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Jordan R Raney
